div1.head: Notes on anti-malarial measures for Camp Lee, by W. F. Draper and Henry Rose Carter, November, 1917
div1.p:
FIELD NOTES ON ANTI-MALARIAL MEASURES NECESSARY IN EXTRA CANTON-
MENT ZONE WITHIN ONE MILE OF CAMP LEE. RESULT OF SURVEY
MADE BY P.A. SURGEON W.F. DRAPER
AND MAJOR HENRY P. CARTER
M.C., U.S.A.
November 1917.
Ettricks.

West of the Battersea mill 500 feet ditch 2 feet wide
one foot deep.

From Old Mill toward river 300 feet ditch 3 feet
wide one foot deep.

East of Mill 100 feet ditch 2 feet wide one foot
deep. Also clean present ditches and remove debris.

Small ponds and puddles in this area should be oiled
at intervals during summer. Estimated cost of oiling for
summer, $10.00
Colonial Heights.

In wet meadow from river up hill, 600 feet ditch
3 feet wide, also 400 feet ditch as side ditches.

From Hillside Spring, Colonial Heights, towards
bridge to river 600 feet ditch, 3 feet wide, 1 ½ feet deep.

West from old stone house towards railroad tressle
1,000 feet of cleaning of ditch already dug.

Survey low area on east side Richmond Turnpike
opposite Aqueduct Spring to see if there are areas need-
ing draining. Open road drain on upper side of road.
Also clean this.
Prince George County.

Petersburg, Camp Lee, Highway fill gravel pit
south side of road just before reaching concrete road.
Estimated cost $10.00.

Clean spring branch at beginning of concrete road
from N. & W. track south 400 to 500 yards.

Ditch and clean meadow triangle between concrete
road and street car tracks south side of road. Will
require 300 feet ditch 2 feet wide 1 foot deep.

Two thousand feet ditch 2 feet wide, 1 foot deep
in Perkinson's meadow extending from spring towards
Petersburg. This must be staked by engineer. Also
4,000 feet 2 feet ditch, 1 foot deep extending from
spring through pasture. Must clean and open up several
thousand feet old channel.

Oil marsh on north side of road 300 yards west of
Lakemont. This will take 1 barrel of oil every six weeks.

Fill in small pool on south side of railroad
opposite marsh.
Field Notes
Camp Lee

1. Pool, Southside Electric R. R., 1,000′, Petersburg side
of Lakemont Park. Moderate sized pool, breeding anopheles freely, also
culex. This close to camp is made by electric railroad's fill. Drain
or fill Drain a fill.

2. Opposite this, between E. R. R. and N. & W. R. R., is a pool
and marsh large. An ideal A. place; breeding A moderately, C freely.
Also pool across R. R. (inside) (N. Side) also breeding.

3. Ditch, S. side N. & W. breeding A. So is one on N. side,
slightly. This is at 2 mile post, N. & W. R

Both (2) and (3) can be drained to creek, Both caused by
N. & W. R. R.

4. Two small pools at Lakemont Park, southside of E. R. R.,
A and C.

5. North of R. R. beyond a cross road, a large swamp, phy-
sically well suited for A. A in moderate number (and C same) found.
Drain into Skipwith Creek.

6. Ditch S. side N. & W. R. R. opposite this place A freely.
Ditch north side, A moderately.
Drain as (5).

7. Ditch Ditch cut to drain N. & W. right of way, running towards
the church at Roseland Park and not far from it. Is full of water and
breeding C. Many Aedes sylvestres in woods adjacent. This ditch is
blocked and the right of way which it should drain, (mainly to the north
of the railroad,) is breeding A and C freely.
Remove obstructions and grade ditch so as to flow & drain R. of way

-2-
8. Down concrete road, one-fourth of a mile and off on road
to southeast, many roadside pools, some permanent. C freely, A moder-
ately. Not of much importance, too far from camp for their size.

9. Afternoon. Out Middle Road from church across Bailey's
Creek, then road east of south. Well at old saw-mill, too deep to dip (Culex?)
Fill with saw-dust. of little importance

10. Hence, a half mile to court House Road and half mile east
on Court House Road to first road leading north, and a half mile on this
road is a pond, blocked by a road, 150′ × 25′, breeding A profusely--
20 at some dips, all sizes.
Drain across road. This will be easy.

Small branch enters this last pond and runs 800′ to con-
nect almost at right angles with what seems to be the ditch from the pond
(examined on 13th) on Court House Road, northeast of infantry barracks.
This pool is shown on plot given Dr. Hillsman, for being within camp.

11. Returned by this same road from Middle to Court House Road,
and 600′ from the latter, on the west side of this road, a pond 100′ ×
15′, breeding A and C both in fair numbers. Pond blocked by road.
Drain at the cross roads, which is easy.
July 16.

Middle section of Harrison's Creek in the woods above
Lakemont. Good deep banks and free flow. No side swamps up to where
pipe line crosses. 600′ higher up is an under-bluff marsh, small and
very shady, runs almost up to the old dam, not much importance unless
cleared. If cleared, to be drained, Culex moderate number -

Above this are a number of side marshes up to the forks
of the creek, all negative and not well suited for A at present, in dense
-3-
growth and far from blood supply. Doubtless breed C, some of which are
taken. Easy to drain if required. First branch on the right negative.
First branch on the left, negative.

Remark It is to be noted that the heavy rains of yesterday and last
night flooded everything, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX washed
out the side pools and left them with so much water that many places
suitable for breeding and which, doubtless, had been breeding, do not
show larvae now.

Norfolk & Western grading camp, near the head of Harrison Creek
(Dark Swamp Run)., at spring

12. Breeding A freely and C profusely in a wide marsh on the
left bank of this run, from the spring down to the road crossing, 600′.
A bad place for breeding but quite far--¾ of a mile from the camp grounds
and further from the buildings.
A stream comes in from the right at the road crossing negative.

Drain the marsh and clear the bed of the stream all the
way down.

Branch coming in on the right above the mule stable, nega-
tive.

So is branch coming in from the right below the crossing,
although there is a pool-(marl pit?) -- xxxxxnear Mr. Haush's house, full of
C.

Some under-cliff marshes on the left side below the road
crossing--of small importance, breeding C only at present, and quite
distant from the camp.

Obstructions should be removed from the bed of Harrison
Creek the whole way down. This is a small job and, with a very little
draining of side marshes, would, I believe, be sufficient. It is doubtful
if this creek is the source of any considerable number of A.

-4-
Afternoon.
Miss Webb's Spring,--Monument, Pa., Regiment.
Just above road crossing, A found--road dam as usual.

13. Valley of stream seems clear of breeding places until about
100′ below the spring. Here, there is a false channel in pools and a
long seepage area, which is permanent, under the bluff. C2breeding pro-
fusely in the latter. No A. (In thick brush).

This creek was entered at several (5) places, and its val-
ley was very dense and rough, but except at this place, no water outside
the creek bed was found. Such may exist however, but it was not possible
with the time at our disposal to explore the creek at all places. We
followed it to its junction with the main creek.

Remove obstructions from the creek bed, which is fairly
deep, and drain any side-pools or under-bluff marsh which may require it.
There are believed to be but few.

This is the right hand fork of Harrison Creek, the other
one having been visited this morning (Dark Swamp Run).

14. About 300′ north of east axex of Webb Spring is another
spring by two poplars. Below this a marshy place, breeding A profusely.
Drain.

Blackwater Creek and its branches was visited and crossed
in a number of places from July 13-17. It is in flood and its valley
and that of its affluents, being very flat and the banks shallow, the
streams were all well out of bank--some 200′ to 300′s wide. No examina-
tion was then possible.

There is no reason to change the plan for the canaliza-
tion of this stream, agreed on with Mr. Messer before the camp was
established. It will probably yield a fair number of pestiferous mos-
quitoes and some A unless much pains is taken. It is not believed to
be a bad place for A, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX but this judjment is
-5-
based on its physical characteristics. No sufficient biological exam-
ination was possible. The valley is densely wooded.

15. There is an area below the signal tower of the N. & W.
R. R., partly caused by its barrow pit, breeding anopheles quite freely,
and which should breed freely later when there is less rain. This area
is on both sides of the track. On the north side extends down to the
bridge over the creek--a branch of Blackwater--and on the south side,
a short distance on both sides of the creek. This about a half mile from
the camp, further from the barracks. It can be easily drained into the
creek. In spite of its distance, I think this should be done.
July 17.

On Blackwater Creek and Branches, all of it within the
reservation.

Creek in flood and close examination impossible. A in swampy
areas in fields near old saw-mill, a half mile southeast of Major Cole's
house--in fair number--woods negative.

This examination was made in wet, the latter part in very wet,
weather. Naturally, then, a number of places breeding in ordinary
weather would have been washed out and found negative in this survey; al-
so, on account of the flooding of pools, larvae were harder to find than
would have been the case normally. A survey in normal weather, then,
would have shown more breeding places and more breeding in such places
than is here indicated.
